title: In chronological order the main literary sources are the following: SOLON: the fragments of Solon’s poetry are most readily available in West
Greek Lyric Poetry (World’s Classics Series
HERODOTUS: most easily available in Aubrey de Selincourt
Herodotus: The Histories

note: The Greek text is in the OCT series under the title Aristotelis Atheniensium Respublica (1920). The work was written between 332 and 322 and
title: Lysistrata/The Acharnians/ The Clouds; David Barrett and Sommerstein, A.H
The Knights/Peace/ The Assemblywomen/Wealth. The Greek text is in two volumes in the OCT series

Aristophanes’ extant plays cover the period 425 to 382. Most of the plays contain material which gives us insights into the way the democracy worked. ‘THE OLD OLIGARCH’: the most accessible translation is Hughes
The Old Oligarch (LACTOR 2

of Classical Teachers. The Greek text is in Xenophontis V: Opuscula (1920) in the OCT series. The work is a pamphlet written probably in the 420s as a critique of Athenian democracy. The author is unknown, but he is clearly not much in sympathy with the system. ARISTOTLE: the work entitled Athenaion Politeia (‘The Athenian Constitution’) is not actually by Aristotle, but probably by one of his pupils

note: Chapters II and IV are specifically on the fourth century, but the other three chapters have much useful detail on the working of the democracy in the fifth century as well as the fourth.
title: details been superseded by more recent work, but it remains a classic of its time and presents a very clear chronological account of how the Athenian democracy developed
Athenian Democracy
is a collection of five separate papers on aspects of Athenian democracy in the fifth and fourth centuries
The World of Athens
is a useful general work, with a very good summary of Athenian democracy in Section 5

note: This book concentrates on the fifth century.
title: The Classical Athenian Democracy
is the most accessible survey of Athenian democracy currently available
